Simple mod_rewrite rules that either pull up the HyperScope
DHTML chrome for a page, or pull the page's XML representation
Note: Mod_Rewrite is a module that comes with Apache and allows
the server to map URLs that come in to different behaviors than
just fetching the file, such as retrieving a different file; the
URL generally stays the same for the end user, in their browser
who does not realize the URL is being remapped.
the HyperScope chrome (i.e. all the DHTML, CSS, JavaScript,
is where the chrome lives - this is how we bootstrap into the UI
If URL has query parameter 'type=xml', such as
OPML XML representation of desired resource; this is used by
chrome's XMLHttpRequest to retrieve XML representation to work

Our native file format is OPML 2.0, documented at
OPML is a simple XML-based file format the has existed for
several years, and which can model an outline document with HTML
and hyperlinks mixed into the outline nodes. It was created by
Dave Weiner, author of RSS and XML-RPC, two successful
OPML is very easy to work with using XPath, XSLT, and the DOM,
We add a number of custom attributes and tags to OPML 2.0 that
are specific to HyperScope; these are all in the namespace
usually preceded with the namespace identifier "hs:",
Custom tags added to the opml:head section
Custom attributes inside opml : body area
Note: Whether this node had an INCLUDE in it, and it's contents
were replaced with the remote include's contents
We will use OPML 2.0s 'include' link type for include links. The
'text' attribute should have the full Augment style INCLUDE
syntax in the OPML 'text' attribute for displaying.
We will add one custom attribute: hs:include-type, which can be
of three values: branch, plex, statement
If this attribute is left off, it defaults to branch.
See http://www.opml.org/spec2#inclusion for details on how OPML
Server-side transforms will need to convert Augment include
Augment-style links must be fully transformed when they reach
The Augment server-side transformer must change the following
Augment-style links into their full HTML style:
Note: Anything that begins with a word, and is followed by --,
is ignored when surrounded by parentheses
These must be transformed into embedded HTML links, with their
We need to support Augment markers in OPML.
This is done with a new tag located in the OPML head element:
Where 'id' is the marker's name, such as 'foobar', and
'location' is a relative Augment style link composed as follows:
It begins with an anchor, #, since it is relative and a link
It is followed by the node ID that contains this marker, such as
Finally, it uses string positioning to offset from the beginning
of the addressed node; this should be a positive string position
offset, and should use character addressing (i.e. +10c, NOT -5w,
Note: When the server-side transforms these values from other
formats that might have embedded HTML, such as XHTML, the string
position should correctly refer to text and NOT HTML characters.
For example, if I had 'hello ', and the marker is at the 'w'
letter, this address should be +7c, NOT +10c, which is what it
would be if we included the HTML in the count. Also, notice that
There can be as many hs:marker elements as you desire, all
embedded in a single hs:markers element in the OPML head
We also have a number of private attributes that are added to
the OPML DOM during Location resolution; these are used in the
final rendering and jumping phases to display a document. These
values should never appear in public OPML documents. They are
usually preceded with the namespace identifier "hs-internal

The Dojo Toolkit - general DHTML framework
Sarissa - Utility library for working with XML, XPath, and XSLT
